text: {{Infobox Writer | name = Nobuko Yoshiya | image = Yoshiya Nobuko.jpg | caption = Nobuko Yoshiya | birth_date = | birth_place = Niigata, Japan | death_date = | death_place = Kamakura, Kanagawa, Japan | occupation = novelist | genre = | movement = | notableworks = }} was a Japanese novelist. She wrote during the Taishō and Showa periods of Japan. She was one of modern Japan's most successful writers. She wrote many romance novels and adolescent girls’ fiction. She was also one of the first writers of Japanese lesbian books, including the Class S genre. ==Early life== Yoshiya was born in Niigata Prefecture, but grew up in the cities of Mooka and Tochigi, in Tochigi Prefecture. Her father was in the public service, so her family often moved. She was the only daughter and youngest child of her family. Both, her mother and her father, came from samurai families.Robertson, Jennifer (2002) "Yoshiya Nobuko Out and Outspoken in Practice and Prose" in Anne Wathall e.d. The Human Tradition in Modern Japan pp. 155-174 She started writing when she was in her teens, although before this she had developed a love for writing which sapped her time for learning domestic skills from her mother. ==References== ===General references=== * Frederick, Sarah.
